title: META Prize and META Seal of Recognition Award Ceremony

author: Lauri Karttunen, Center for the Study of Language and Information, Stanford University
recorded by: German Research Center for Artificial Intelligence (DFKI)

segmentation: Greetings, I'm louder character and.
Unfortunately, I cannot be there in person.
I'm making this video in Austin, TX and I hope to reach you through YouTube.

I'm honored to receive the Meta Seal of recognition for the extra 50 application in behalf, not just myself with Xerox, Xerox Research Centre, Europe and Palo Alto Research Center and the many other Xerox people who have contributed to the success of FST over the years.
You
Can see some of the names on the title slide of my presentation.
They include Ron Kaplan, who together with Martin Kay introduced me to find our state technology many years ago.
And my colleagues at Texas EE.
Can beastly Andre Camper and Thomas call?
So.
What is XFST?
It's a standalone Unix application that serves two purposes.
It compiles finite state networks from strings, TXT files and regular expressions.
Using finance that calculus operations such as concatenation, intersection, composition, complementation, and so forth.
The second purpose of XFT is to apply finite state transducers to strings or text files for all kinds of purposes, including tokenization, morphological analysis, and generation and pattern matching.
So FST is both a development tool and a runtime tool.
What is surface T used for?
FST and its sister applications have been used over the years to create morphological analyzers.
Another link where for dozens of languages they include the major European languages and quite a few exotic ones such as Sami coarser and raucous.
Most of the work on the exotic languages has been done by academic research groups, but X. FST also has commercial users.
Xerox has licensed it to several other companies.
The current users include ASAP and Microsoft, but both run unenhanced industrial version of Excel 50.
What?
About the future.
I retired from Xerox Parc last year and I succeeded getting Xerox to agree to make the source code of XFST and it's enhanced version available under a click through license for non commercial use.
The details are still being worked out, but if all goes as planned the source code of Exodus T will be available sometime this year.
Keep an eye on my Stanford website for the announcement.
Thank you again for this recognition and goodbye from Austin, TX.
